gnojek

I'd just like to know this one little tidbit.
 
 Creationists can never succinctly define what they mean when they sue the word "kind" as in a Biblical "kind."
 
 They say that there can even be variation within a kind, a sort of Biblical evolutionary theory, whereby species develop within the broader "kind" classifiacation.
 
 I'm sure this has been asked before, but are humans of the ape kind or are apes of the human kind?
 
 In Genesis, humans are created seperately from all other creatures, but apes and monkeys are not specifically mentioned.
 
 Were there even apes and monkeys on the ark, or did they evolve from humans, since we must be of the same Biblical kind?
 
 Any insight into this foolishness will be appreciated.
Kronus

Well, Genesis has God making all the animals "and their kind", and then when he's done with that he makes humans. So I would assume that humans don't fit into the "kind" schema, or perhaps are a kind unto themselves. The similarity between us and apes is just coincidence. We can't be of the same kind as apes, because (based on the only "definition" of kind I've heard) micro-evolution can turn one species into another within "kinds", and humans can't turn into anything, or vice-versa.
supergrunt

Hmmm... I have heard creationists argue the "kinds" theory to explain the huge dimorphism we see in humans, from little Bushman to giant Somoans...
 
 So apparently we can micro-evolve within our kind. But then again, aren't we supposed to be made in the image of God? Can God evlove?
Kronus

Can God evlove?

 
 Well, he certainly shows distinct difference between the old and the new testaments!
pandion

Creationists can never succinctly define what they mean when they sue the word "kind" as in a Biblical "kind."
It isn't that they can't, they usually go to extremes to duck the question. However, various creationist sources have defined "kind" as equivalent to the biological classification of species, genus, and sometimes even family. Most educated creationists have realized that the definition of "kind" at the most intuitive level, the species, turns the story of the ark to nonsense, and start moving the definition up to higher taxonomic levels.
 
They say that there can even be variation within a kind, a sort of Biblical evolutionary theory, whereby species develop within the broader "kind" classifiacation.
Yes. But that means that the cat "kind", a single pair, produced 4 genera with 36 species in, at most, a couple hundred years. And that doesn't even include domestic cats. It makes the head of any evolutionary biologist spin! Creationists who wish to deny evolution invoke hyperevolution for thousands of "kinds" to yield millions of species in hundreds of years. And yet, they deny evolution.
 
I'm sure this has been asked before, but are humans of the ape kind or are apes of the human kind?
Well, man has been called the third chimpanzee. Cladistics is some decades old now, and it has suplanted the old Linean system. While discoveries are still assigned genus and species names, evaluation of morphological charisteristics by computer yield much more realistic evolutionary trees.
 
In Genesis, humans are created seperately from all other creatures, but apes and monkeys are not specifically mentioned.
But on the other hand, Genesis isn't a scientific document. No wonder. Why would a bronze age nomad from the Levant be aware of at least 3 tailless species of primates, or even the tailed primates from Africa, South America, and even Madigascar. If they aren't mentioned in the Bible, do they exist?
 
Were there even apes and monkeys on the ark, or did they evolve from humans, since we must be of the same Biblical kind?

 Couldn't have evolved from humans since evolution is an invention of Satan.
 
Any insight into this foolishness will be appreciated.
And my answer in intended in the spirit of your original post.
gnojek

We can't be of the same kind as apes, because (based on the only "definition" of kind I've heard) micro-evolution can turn one species into another within "kinds", and humans can't turn into anything, or vice-versa.

 So we can't base our definition of "kind" on mere appearances?
 
 I mean if we are going to put things into categories and call the category "kind", we should do this by common appearances. A penguin is in the same kind as a hummingbird, but is a lobster in the same kind as an oyster? Obviously a lobster and a shrimp would be in the same kind, but could a dolphin and a manatee be in the same kind? Did they evolve from a common ancestor kind?
 
 And since apes look and act so much like humans, didn't they just evolve from humans? By all appearances, they we must all be in the same kind.
gnojek

It isn't that they can't, they usually go to extremes to duck the question. However, various creationist sources have defined "kind" as equivalent to the biological classification of species, genus, and sometimes even family. Most educated creationists have realized that the definition of "kind" at the most intuitive level, the species, turns the story of the ark to nonsense, and start moving the definition up to higher taxonomic levels.

 In other words God had the Linnean classification scheme in mind when he wrote the Noah story.
 
 
 
But on the other hand, Genesis isn't a scientific document. No wonder. Why would a bronze age nomad from the Levant be aware of at least 3 tailless species of primates, or even the tailed primates from Africa, South America, and even Madigascar. If they aren't mentioned in the Bible, do they exist?

 At least around Roman times (NT times) they had all kinds of animals to throw in with the Christians and the Gladiators. I don't know if they knew about Orangs and Gorillas though, especially in OT times.
 
 
Couldn't have evolved from humans since evolution is an invention of Satan.

 Or the Noah story could be an invention of Satan since it's meant to confuse.
 Did 5 million species fit on the ark? Did 5000 kinds that subsequently underwent rapid evolution? Did the gorillas come from the line of Shem, orangs from the line of Ham, and chimps from the line of Japheth? It had to be that way. 
 
 Antedeluvian humans (of the more general human kind) were a lot more hairy then and very huge and strong (strong enough to build the titanic ark). After the flood, and because we are flawed creatures because of the fall, we decayed (via the 2nd law) into seperate lines of what we call apes, and perhaps even monkeys. I mean, these things are self-evident.
thebootfitter

It isn't that they can't, they usually go to extremes to duck the question.

 I was just thinking... "Isn't it funny that no 'creationists' have posted on this thread yet. Hmm...
Kronus

I mean if we are going to put things into categories and call the category "kind", we should do this by common appearances. A penguin is in the same kind as a hummingbird, but is a lobster in the same kind as an oyster? Obviously a lobster and a shrimp would be in the same kind, but could a dolphin and a manatee be in the same kind? Did they evolve from a common ancestor kind?
 

 
 I have never, once, seen a Creationist actually make a list of what the kinds are, and what animals belong to them. They will say there is a canine kind, to which dogs and wolves belong, and maybe one or two other obvious ones like felines, but that's the greatest commitment I've ever seen. If anyone claims to be a Scientific creationist I bring this up, and ask why no one has done the science of actually sorting out the kinds. This doesn't make them happy. 
 
 If one were to try to sort the kinds I guess you'ld start with animal A, and through selective breeding try to get something that looked like animal B. If you could do it, then they would be of the same kind. So shrimp and lobster would almost certainly be the same kind, but I bet creationists wouldn't say manatees and dolphins are the same (if you could get them to commit at all) since you couldn't easily breed a blowhole into a manatee.
pandion

I have never, once, seen a Creationist actually make a list of what the kinds are, and what animals belong to them. They will say there is a canine kind, to which dogs and wolves belong, and maybe one or two other obvious ones like felines, but that's the greatest commitment I've ever seen.
Actually, the debate on this one was hard to miss 8 or 9 years ago. John Woodmorappe, in his book, Noah's Ark: A Feasibility Study, Inst for Creation Research (July 1, 1996), 298 pp., ISBN: 0932766412 did exactly that. Essentially Woodmorappe equated "kinds" to genus in most cases, with an occasional family that contained an inordinate number of genera thrown in where he couldn't make all of them fit. Woody came up with 15,754 "kinds", and calculates that there would have been enough room on the ark for all of them. He also calculated the room requirements based on the median size of the animals rather than the average size. Of course, he leaves off all plants, arthropods, mollusks, fish, and aquatic mammals. I don't recall if he included the dinosaurs, but Ken Ham, Kent Hovind, Carl Baugh and the like have them on the ark.
 
 You correctly assume that the creationist story would be that there was a "dog king" and a "cat kind" from which all species evolved in a few years after the flood. Never mind that a single pair of cats could not possibly carry enough genetic diversity to evolve all 36 species of cat in 4 genera, not even in the 4,500 years since the flood was claimed to have occurred. In order to cram all the "kinds" on the ark, creationists must leave off everything but mammals and birds (without ever explaining how they could have survived a flood that lasted a year), and then propose hyper-evolution at rates that make evolutionary biologists dizzy, calling it "variation in kind."
 
 It should also be noted that "John Woodmorappe" is a pen name of Jan Peczkis, a science teacher from Chicago with a degree in earth science. Besides his young earth creationist articles as Woodmorappe, Peczkis has also published old earth articles in peer reviewed literature. At one time Peczkis threatened to sue several people on the internet who revealed the duplicity (one being Joe Meert of the University of Florida geology department. Radiometric Dating, Paleosols and the Geologic Column). If he consulted a lawyer, I'm sure that he was laughed out of the office, since you can't sue someone for slander if what they say is true.
 
 A review of Woodmorappe's book and other interesting links can be found at Talk Origins. You can buy the book at amazon.com for $44.50.
 
If anyone claims to be a Scientific creationist I bring this up, and ask why no one has done the science of actually sorting out the kinds. This doesn't make them happy.
I'm surprised that no one has ever mentioned the book before. Even though there is nothing but ad hoc answers to the questions, creationists touted the book as "proof" that Noah's ark was possible. They never seem to notice that no one has ever tried to build and float an ark. They prefer to put the money into creation museums and amusement parks.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Are humans of the ape "kind"?
